DESCRIPTION: Salem Progressive Film Series Begins Season with "jolting and powerful" film:

ACTION NAME: SPFS FILM: The Exonerated

DATES: Sep 10, 2009 through Sep 10, 2009

TIME: 7:00 pm

ORGANIZATION: Salem Progressive Film Series

DESCRIPTION: Salem Progressive Film Series Begins Season with "jolting and powerful" film:

The Exonerated
Sept. 10th, 7PM 
The Grand Theater, 
191 High St. NE
downtown Salem,OR


Salem’s Progressive Film Series (SPFS), kicks off their 2009-2010 offerings with a presentation of The Exonerated, an award-winning film and stage play. The film presents the true stories of six exonerated survivors of death row. While every bit of dialogue in the film is true and documented, it is only a glimpse into the lives of the 135 people, since 1976 released from death row prison sentences, after they were proven innocent. An all-star cast, including Danny Glover, Susan Sarandon, Brian Dennehy, is featured in the film described as ‘jolting”, “powerful” and "stories you will never forget" by critics and viewers alike.

As is the custom with SPSF events, a discussion will take place following the film presentation. Guest speaker will be Curtis McCarty who was exonerated in 2007 after serving 21 years…19 years on death row, for a 1982 murder he didn’t commit. His freedom was granted after DNA evidence was presented and proof of prosecutorial misconduct by the State’s chief forensic analyst was proven. The great number of cases, such as Curtis McCarty’s, are causing people throughout the United States to question the ability of the criminal justice system to adequately and fairly administer a death penalty. 

Joining Mr. McCarty will be Ron Steiner, a community organizer with Oregonians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty (OADP). Mr. Steiner was an active member of the New Mexico Coalition to Repeal the Death Penalty, leading up to that state’s March 2009 repeal. He is also a member of the national board of directors of Murder Victims’ Families for Reconciliation.

The Salem Progressive Film Series takes place the second Thursday of each month. The September film presentation and discussion will be Sept. 10th, 7PM at The Grand Theater, 191 High St. NE, downtown Salem. Major sponsors of SPFS include The Historic Grand Theater, Salem Monthly and Willamette Valley Vineyards. 

Peter Bergel, Executive Director of Oregon Peace Works, one of the on-going sponsors of the film series, says regarding the death penalty, “Almost all of us know in our hearts that killing others feels wrong. Moreover, it is ineffective as a deterrent and expensive as a punishment. That leaves only ‘getting even’ as a motivation and that’s not worth it.” 

Dr. Bill Long, former Willamette U. law professor and chair of the Outreach Committee of OADP, stated that "On top of all the other problems with the death penalty, one that gives great pause for concern is the possibility that we might execute an innocent person." Curtis McCarty will give testimony to how close we come to that horrible outcome.

For more information on the SPFS, visit http://www.salemprogressivefilms.net or call (503) 588-8713 or (503) 779-5288

item.content:encoded:
Tobin Lecture

November 14, 2009

Keynote Address

All Saints Catholic Church, Portland, Oregon

Tobin Lecture

November 14, 2009

Keynote Address

All Saints Catholic Church, Portland, Oregon

Speaker, Clarence Pugh, Chair, Oregonians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty 

Thank you. 

Chancellor Tully, Father Thompson, fellow panelists, ladies and gentlemen, it is an honor to give the keynote address, today, and to be with my distinguished colleagues on the panel who will speak about issues involving Respect for Life. 

I would like to begin by honoring the memory of Dr. Bill Connor, long time member and Chair Emeritus of Oregonians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty.  Dr. Connor died on October 25 after a life of service to human rights and to abolition of the death penalty.  Dr. Connor - “Bill” to many of us – was a wise and gentle guide.   We miss him greatly.   

The text from Matthew 25, Verses 31-40 has particular meaning for me in my journey through the jungles of the death penalty. 

31 When the Son of man comes in his glory, and all the angels with him, then he will sit on his glorious throne. 32 Before him will be gathered all the nations, and he will separate them one from another as a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats, 33 and he will place the sheep at his right hand, but the goats at the left.  34 Then the King will say to those at his right hand, ‘Come, O blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world; 35 for I was hungry and you gave me food, I was thirsty and you gave me drink, I was a stranger and you welcomed me, 36 I was naked and you clothed me, I was sick and you visited me, I was in prison and you came to me.’  37 Then the righteous will answer him, ‘Lord, when did we see thee hungry and feed thee, or thirsty and give thee drink?  38 And when did we see thee a stranger and welcome thee, or naked and clothe thee? 39 And when did we see thee sick or in prison and visit thee?’ 

40  And the King will answer them, ‘Truly, I say to you, as you did it to one of the least of these my brethren, you did it to me.’ 

From an early time in my life I realized that the way some people treat each other is disrespectful and hurtful in a way that denies the most basic aspects of their humanity.   

Those were the years when the Rosenberg trial took place - the McCarthy years, when a great fear of communist influence gained traction in the United States.  That fear was exploited by nefarious politicians, many of whom went on to long careers in government.  Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were accused, tried, convicted, and sentenced to death for treason for giving atomic bomb secrets to the Soviet Union.  The trial, sentencing, and execution transfixed citizens all over the country and I was no different.  I remember sitting by the radio listening to the broadcasts – and then the live news reports of the execution.  The graphic descriptions of how long it took to kill Ethel Rosenberg, how many jolts of electricity were given, the commentary that she was “too mean” to die quickly, left me fascinated and horrified.  I remember wondering about their children who were close to the same age as I was – about 10 years old.  What were they going to do?  I couldn’t imagine losing my parents – especially having them taken away from me like that. 

I think that’s when my questioning of the death penalty began.  Not that I spent the next many years consumed with the issue.  I didn’t really return to it again until 1989 when I was living in Japan and joined an English-speaking Amnesty International group.   

I took on the task of organizing a letter writing campaign within our group to the Governor of a state in the United States where an execution was to take place.  The injustice embodied in the thought that a government could take the life of a person in revenge for a terrible crime galvanized my activism against the death penalty. 

When my wife and I returned home to Oregon in 1991 we renewed our acquaintance with Mike Hall, a retired Methodist minister, who was one of the founders of the Oregon Coalition to Abolish the Death Penalty.  OCADP was founded in 1983 to oppose the reinstitution of Oregon’s death penalty which had been abolished in 1964.   

I became more knowledgeable about the death penalty. It was apparent that its destructive influence on society, and the flaws in its implementation, were more important than any of the promises made to get it approved by the people. 

The death penalty denies the humanity of the person sentenced to death.  Some feel that a person who has murdered another human being has forfeited his or her right to live.  Sister Helen Prejean, however, has said that a person is better than the worst thing they have done.

We hear the Bible quoted as a justification for capital punishment: "Eye for eye, tooth for tooth" (from Exodus 21:24 and Leviticus 24:20) and the more direct passage: "Whoever takes the life of any human being shall be put to death" (from Leviticus 24:17).  This justification is incorrect.  Sister Helen, again, explains that the well-known "eye for eye" passage was originally intended to limit violence by reducing its escalation. In Matthew 5:38-42, Jesus disallows even that limited violence.

Emphasizing the passages from Genesis and Leviticus ignores other similar passages in which death is decreed for one who works on the Sabbath (Exodus 31: Verse 15) or for one who curses one's parent (Exodus 21: Verse 17) or even for a rebellious teenager (Deuteronomy 21: Verses 18-21).”  I believe, as many theologians do, that the Bible’s passages must be considered in the context of their times.

We have long ago stopped executing those who don’t worship on the Sabbath or who sass their parents.  If we hadn’t, a lot of us would have been in trouble, don’t you think?

In spite of historic public support for the death penalty, people have always been uncomfortable with it.  The hundreds of crimes that once carried the death penalty have been winnowed down to a relative few. 

In 1972 the U.S. Supreme Court threw out the death penalty laws in all states, saying that their imposition was so arbitrary and “capricious,” it was given for so many crimes and so unevenly, that it amounted to “cruel and unusual punishment” and could not be considered constitutional.  They left the door open, however, for states to re-introduce the death penalty with new laws, which happened in 1976.

As a result, imposition of the death penalty has been limited to those who have committed murder - usually when committed in the course of carrying out certain other crimes or murder of persons in certain protected categories.  In Oregon, that is called “Aggravated Murder.” 

The methods of execution have also been changed, usually because the ones being used offended the watchers’ sensibilities.  We no longer draw and quarter people.  So-called “better” ways were developed, often using more modern technology.  In relatively modern times beheading was left behind by hanging, which was supplanted by the use of lethal gas, which was replaced by electrocution, which was succeeded by lethal injection.  Each of these in turn was thought to be more respectful of life – even as the life was taken away.  And, of course, the state – that is to say, the people – no longer carries out executions in direct sight of the citizenry, as was done in Oregon as late as 1903.  Not that public interest is not morbidly high and not that every detail is not broadcast by the media.  But I believe our guilt, even if it is not admitted, has made us construct a façade around executions.

We have also constructed an elaborate process around the death penalty.  We do this to attempt to ensure that mistakes aren’t made and the accused has been given every chance. - “Due Process of Law.”  However, there has been a pushback by politicians and the public that has eroded this carefully designed system.  In 1993 Congress passed, and President Bill Clinton signed, the “Anti-Terrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act (AEDPA)” that

  • placed stringent limits on the length of time appeals at any step could take 
  • and limited the length of briefs filed in the case.  Briefs need to be lengthy when there are important issues to be raised.  One Oregon defendant is currently limited to a 25 page brief at one step in his appeal. 
  • It enforced the “deference” that succeeding courts had to give to previous courts and the jury in the decisions that had been made.  That meant that, even if wrong decisions had been made at those earlier levels, the standard for changing them was much higher.  Justice Antonin Scalia recently said in his opinion on the Troy Davis case, which was joined by Justice Clarence Thomas, “This court has never held that the Constitution forbids the execution of a convicted defendant who has had a full and fair trial but is later able to convince a habeas court that he is ‘actually’ innocent.”

    Professor Alan Dershowitz of Harvard Law School responded:  “Let us be clear precisely what this means. If a defendant were convicted, after a constitutionally unflawed trial, of murdering his wife, and then came to the Supreme Court with his very much alive wife at his side, and sought a new trial based on newly discovered evidence (namely that his wife was alive), these two justices would tell him, in effect: “Look, your wife may be alive as a matter of fact, but as a matter of constitutional law, she’s dead, and as for you, Mr. Innocent Defendant, you’re dead, too, since there is no constitutional right not to be executed merely because you’re innocent.”

This strikes me as the ultimate lack of Respect for Life!

The basis for Oregon’s modern death penalty law was passed by the people via initiative petition in 1984.  The Legislature and the Oregon Supreme Court have modified it numerous times in the intervening years.  Since the first death sentences were imposed in 1986. 

2 have been executed.  18 have had their sentences commuted to life sentences, died, or been released. 

  • 2 of those commutations occurred recently when the men were finally acknowledged as being developmentally disabled.  The U.S. Supreme Court, in the Atkins decision, banned execution of people who are mentally retarded.  Jesse Pratt served 21 years and Mike McNeely 16 years on Oregon’s death row before the state agreed to the commutation to LWOPP.
  • Several men are mentally ill:  two are severe enough to have appointed guardians ad litem to take their place in legal proceedings.
  • There remain 33 men on death row. 

 

Several have been retried and re-sentenced to death multiple times.  Every time they are re-sentenced their appeals start over.  8 of the men have been on death row over 20 years.  Some could be on death row for 40 years before they are executed. 

  • 12 percent of Oregon’s death row identifies primarily as African American, whereas
  • 2% of Oregon’s population is African American. 
  • 12 percent of Oregon’s death row population identifies primarily as Native American, whereas,
  • 1% of Oregon’s population is Native American.

 

Oregon’s death penalty is based on Texas’s scheme:  That means there are Two trials.  The first trial, the Guilt Phase, determines the defendant’s guilt or innocence.  If the defendant is found guilty there is a second Penalty Phase trial in which the jury must decide which sentence to impose – death, life with a 30-year minimum sentence, or life without the possibility of parole.   

If the defendant is sentenced to death, there are a possible 10 steps of appeal through Oregon state courts, the federal courts, and the Governor. 

In 1991, Oregon’s death penalty sentencing scheme was overturned when Texas’ law was overturned by the U.S. Supreme Court. The Court added a requirement that the jury consider evidence of mitigating circumstances in the defendant’s favor.  

As a result, all of the 23 men then on death row were sent back for new penalty phase trials.  12 were re-sentenced to death.  11 were given life sentences. 

So, given a new look at the cases, either the State of Oregon or new juries decided for life instead of death in nearly 50% of the cases. 

Overall, the Trend in the U.S. is downward. 

Since 1995, Death sentences have declined by 2/3. 

Executions have declined by 57 percent since 2000. 

And in Oregon, in the 4 years between 1987 and 1991, Oregon sentenced 22 people to death.  But since then Oregon has averaged 1-2 death sentences per year.   

In some years there are no Oregon death sentences. 

Prosecutors say they need the death penalty because it makes defendants plead guilty and accept Life Without the Possibility of Parole sentences.  But Massachusetts has no death penalty and their prosecutions result in many LWOP sentences.  In New Jersey, which repealed the death penalty in 2007, prosecutors say they don’t need the death penalty in order to get LWOP sentences.   

Are citizens safer in states with the death penalty? 

Of the 20 states with the highest murder rates in the country in 2008, all had the death penalty.  The South has accounted for over 80% of executions since 1976.  The South also has the highest murder rate.  The Northeast is lowest, with the West and the Midwest in between.  Only one state in the Northeast region has the death penalty.  Oregon’s murder rate is 2.1 per 100,000 population.  This is well below the West regional average of 4.8. 

Oregon was promised that the death penalty would be reserved for the “worst of the worst.”  Yet, prosecutors routinely offer plea deals to one defendant in return for testimony against the other.  Often a defendant who was most or equally culpable, but is more capable of making decisions in their own best interest, pleads out and the other receives the death penalty or LWOPP after a trial.   

This is not to excuse criminals for the crimes they have committed.  It is to illustrate that “the worst of the worst” are not necessarily the ones who end up sentenced to death. 

Cost of the death penalty in Oregon 

The cost of the death penalty and the risk of executing innocent people give us "practical reasons" to reconsider it.

Every dollar spent on a death penalty case is a dollar we cannot spend in positive ways anywhere else.  The State of Oregon bears the major costs for death penalty prosecutions and defense because almost every defendant in a murder case is poor. 

The largest costs, at this point, come from the initial two-part trial.   

Both the prosecution and the defense are required to have 2 attorneys, and to have investigators, and specialists on mitigation, forensics, mental health, and future dangerousness.   

Death penalty trials are much longer than murder trials without the death penalty.  Jury selection is a longer and more arduous process because juries must be “death qualified.”  All jurors must agree that they are willing to consider imposing a death sentence.  To impanel this kind of jury, larger numbers of potential jurors must be called and questioned.  Jurors who cannot consider a death sentence will be excluded.   

The American Bar Association has compiled average nationwide costs for death versus non-death penalty murder trials. 

2004-2008 data showed that defense costs averaged  $213,000 per case for death penalty cases. 

Straight murder cases, without the death penalty, averaged $24,000 per case, or 1/10 of the cost of an aggravated murder case. 

A very conservative estimate from the year 2000 would be that the State of Oregon and its counties were spending at least $9 million each year on pursuing the capital prosecutions of fewer than 90 individuals,  - those with active appeals on death row, and those new defendants coming into the system  

There are now 3 Oregon death row prisoners who have reached the federal level of appeals.  The costs at this level are expected to be very high.   

So many resources are going into the first cases because Oregon’s current death penalty law has not been fully reviewed by the U.S. Supreme Court.  The most advanced of these cases will be the first from Oregon to reach the federal level.  The federal decisions made will determine the case law for future Oregon cases. 

At this point, none of the cases have reached the 9th U.S. Circuit Court.  They are still in federal district court in Portland. 

Innocence 

One way to respect life is to protect innocent people.   

The leading proponents of the death penalty in Oregon say that Oregon has never sentenced an innocent person to death.  This is a misleading statement because it doesn’t tell us why there have been no innocent persons identified.  Nationwide data shows that it can take 20-30 years to develop the evidence that shows that a person sentenced to death is actually innocent.   

The statement is also misleading because Oregon has had five innocent people sentenced for murder, (in some cases, aggravated murder), but not to death.  Santiago Ventura Morales, John Sosnovski, Irene Pavlinek, Christopher Boots, and Eric Proctor.  Sosnovski even pled guilty in order to avoid the possibility of being sentenced to death. 

A sixth man Scott Cannon was convicted of a triple murder and sentenced to LWOP in 1999.  After 11 years, his conviction has been overturned but he is being held in Polk County while the District Attorney decides whether to retry him.  In addition to many other weaknesses in the case he was convicted on the basis of a now debunked forensic tool called Bullet Lead Analysis.  Bullet Lead Analysis was based on the idea that the batch from which a single bullet came could be identified and tied to other bullets in the accused person’s possession. This was a standard forensic tool used by law enforcement agencies from the FBI to the local levels.  The FBI has now recognized that it is not possible to match one bullet to another by batch. 

Other technologies were also once considered “state of the art,” but were later found to be without scientific validity.  Microscopic hair analysis is one that has resulted in numbers of people sentenced to death in other states.   

People have even been executed because their attorneys missed filing deadlines by minutes.  The AEDPA effectively cut off defendants’ ability to prove their innocence if the issues weren’t raised in their original trial or at earlier stages of the appeals.   

There have been 1,181 people executed in the U.S. between 1976 and November 12, 2009.    In that time 139 people have been released from death row nationwide because of their innocence.  So, for every 8 people executed, one person has been found to be innocent.  That’s a 12 percent error rate. A 12 percent error rate would be unacceptable in any other field. 

According to The Innocence Project, there have been 244 people exonerated of crimes by DNA evidence across the country. 17 of the 244 people exonerated (7%) through DNA served time on death row.

This only tells part of the story, though, because most cases have no medical forensic evidence.  Experts estimate that only 5 to 10 percent of criminal cases in the U.S. involve biological evidence, and there is consensus that proving innocence on appeal without the scientific proof of DNA results can, to say the least, be an uphill battle.  (The Innocence Project, 9-2009) 

We can shorten the process but we then find we are executing innocent people.  The Willingham case from Texas, in which the arson evidence has been thoroughly refuted and the man has been shown to have been innocent, shows that at least one innocent person has been executed.  The 12 percent error rate in death sentences shows that there are likely many more.  Oregon’s wrongful conviction rate is very worrying and should grab the attention of all thoughtful citizens and legislators.   

Do we have to wait until we have executed somebody, only to find out later that he or she was innocent, before we admit that we don’t need the death penalty in Oregon? 

What will we do if we find out that one of the current folks on death row is actually innocent? 

How high of an error rate are we willing to accept in Oregon? 

From a practical standpoint, the death penalty is deeply flawed. 

The human costs, and the cost to the soul of society, must be considered by all  enlightened people. 

It is said that having the death penalty brings “closure” for the families of murder victims.  However, murder victims’ survivors tell us that in reality, there is no “closure.”  Killing another person will not close the book on the murder of a loved one because, for survivors, the memories of their loved one will always be there.  The process delays the time when the survivors will be able to work through their grief. 

The judges and the citizens who are called to jury service must make these terrible decisions. They are all caught up in a process that will stay with them for the rest of their lives.  Many jury members have reported lingering doubts and guilt over the decisions they had made. 

Two groups of people who are rarely mentioned in the context of the death penalty are those who carry out the executions, and the family members of the executed persons.  They suffer, too.  They have grief.  But they are ignored.  Those who carry out executions commonly suffer from guilt, remorse, conflicted feelings, and, sometimes Post Traumatic Stress Syndrome. 

The execution procedure is not foolproof.   On September 15, in the latest of many botched executions around the country, the state of Ohio failed in its attempt to execute death row prisoner Romell Broom. Guards spent two hours unsuccessfully trying to find suitable veins for the lethal injection, even with Broom's assistance while he was strapped down on the death table.  Some of the IV injection personnel walked out saying they couldn’t take it anymore. 

Why would we want to put our public servants through that kind of trauma?  The human costs of taking people’s lives are too high.

The ex-wife of John Muhammad, who was executed on November 12 by the State of Virginia, said she and their three children watched news coverage of his execution in silence at their Maryland home.  When his death was announced, the children – John 19, Salena, 17, and Taalibah, 16 – went into different rooms and cried.  “It was very difficult to see them in that kind of pain,” she said.  “Because I know what was going through their head – “This is my dad, he should be in my life, this should not be happening.” 

There are better ways, and ways that emphasize how precious life is.  Mahatma Gandhi said “An Eye For An Eye Makes the Whole World Blind.” 

THERE ARE ALTERNATIVES TO THE DEATH PENALTY.  For our sake and the sake of our humanity we need to get rid of the death penalty. 

The tide is changing. 

This is true for the population as a whole.  As Archbishop Vlazny said in his article in the Catholic Sentinel, “More and more of our Catholic people seem to be getting the message.  Less than half now support the death penalty.  For those who attend church regularly, support of the death penalty decreases even more.” 

Chiefs of Police across the nation say that having the death penalty is the least effective tool in lowering violent crime.   

States are abolishing their death penalties.  New Jersey’s and New Mexico’s legislatures repealed theirs.  New York’s was struck down by their Supreme Court and their legislature has not reinstated it.   

Montana, Colorado, Illinois, Kansas, and Maryland all had serious efforts at repeal in their last legislatures.  Montana and Colorado are very close. 

Death sentences are down by nearly half.  Executions are down by two thirds. 

So there is national movement on this issue. 

In Oregon there is new vigor in the death penalty abolition movement.  Over the past two years, activists, led by Oregonians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty,  

  • have met with leaders from the states that have achieved abolition to learn their successful strategies,
  • convened meetings with a wide array of organizations and individuals to create a truly state-wide movement,
  • reinvigorated our Board of Directors, bringing on board people with wisdom and experience in organizational development and planning,
  • created an Outreach Committee to develop and manage the program that will build the statewide movement, including media, speaking, events, and recruiting volunteers at the local and statewide levels, and have
  • created a People of Faith Committee to reach out to the faith community, who are our natural allies in the effort,

 

I am pleased to say these efforts are bearing fruit. 

  • The Archdiocese of Portland’s Chancellor, Mary Jo Tully is a very welcome addition to OADP’s Board,
  • The Oregon-Idaho Conference of the United Methodist Church maintains its long-time representation on OADP’s Board,
  • Our Faith Committee is working with all of the denominations and faith organizations to develop statements against the death penalty and have them posted on our website.  There are now several and more come in regularly.
  • The bishops of several denominations discussed creating an interdenominational statement against the death penalty,
  • Speaking events are significantly up – to the point where we need to scramble to fill them all.  We are also attracting new people with knowledge and ability to add to our cadre of speakers,
  • The Board will conduct a strategic planning event this Winter,
  • Part of the strategic planning will be consideration of whether the time will be ripe to move for a legislative referral of a repeal measure to the people in 2011 with a possible vote of the people in 2012,
  • That decision has not been mace.  Many threads will need to intertwine for it to happen.

 

We invite all caring people to join in this effort.  We reach out most strongly to the Catholic Church because of the Church’s teachings in the areas of Respect for All Life. 

Archbishop Vlazny in the Catholic Sentinel wrote, 

“As Catholics, we are committed to promoting a consistent ethic of life and upholding the dignity of life from conception until natural death. We emphatically oppose a culture of death. We cannot promote the illusion that we can protect life by taking life. 

Catholic teaching on the death penalty clearly articulates a call for us to set aside all unnecessary violence, including violence by the state, on the basis of the dignity of each and every person and the building of a culture of life. 

This is consistent with everything we have learned about Catholic support for the sanctity of human life. The more active people are in practicing their faith, the more they understand and appreciate the value of human life as a gift from God, one where we exercise some stewardship, but not ownership.” 

Jesus said, “Truly, I say to you, as you did it to one of the least of these my brethren, you did it to me.” 

Thank you.

item.title: Does Oregon currently have the death penalty?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Capital punishment is legal in the U.S. state of Oregon. The first execution under the territorial government was in 1851. Capital punishment was made explicitly legal by statute in 1864, and executions have been carried out exclusively at the Oregon State Penitentiary in Salem since 1904. The death penalty was outlawed between 1914 and 1920, again between 1964 and 1978, and then again between a 1981 Oregon Supreme Court ruling and a 1984 ballot measure.

Capital punishment is legal in the U.S. state of Oregon. The first execution under the territorial government was in 1851. Capital punishment was made explicitly legal by statute in 1864, and executions have been carried out exclusively at the Oregon State Penitentiary in Salem since 1904. The death penalty was outlawed between 1914 and 1920, again between 1964 and 1978, and then again between a 1981 Oregon Supreme Court ruling and a 1984 ballot measure.

Since 1904, about 60 individuals have been executed in Oregon. Aggravated murder is the only crime subject to the penalty of death under Oregon law.

item.title: About OADP
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Who we are:

We are criminal justice activists joined in a concerted effort to increase the effectiveness of Oregon's response to violent interpersonal crime. Our members include victims' survivors, attorneys, religious leaders, teachers and other concerned citizens.

Oregonians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty (OADP) evolved out of the Oregon Coalition to Abolish the Death Penalty, which was organized in 1983. OADP is incorporated in the State of Oregon as a non-profit organization with the purpose of research and education on the effectiveness of the death penalty and its alternatives. We have 501(c)3 status.

We have an Education and Outreach Committee and a Correspondents Committee. We maintain a list of relevant educational materials, support research, provide speakers, find people to correspond with and visit prisoners on death row, and sponsor events with the aim of raising public awareness.

Our Goals:

OADP works towards repeal of the death penalty

OADP supports life sentence alternatives in response to aggravated murder as effective and sufficient punishment

OADP promotes research, education and discussion of issues relating to the death penalty

OADP works to promote principles of restorative justice for all those affected by murder, including victims' family members, prisoners and prisoners' families.

We oppose the Death Penalty because:

It encourages the idea that violence is an appropriate solution to social problems

It has, and will continue to result in the execution of innocent people

It is not an effective deterrent to murder

It is applied arbitrarily and disproportionately against the poor and minorities

It diverts resources from effective criminal justice policy

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
An editorial The Daily Astorian, contrasts the state’s use of funds for the death penalty to the state's reduction in funding for education.  “The glaring contrast to our unquestioning spending on the death penalty - which Judge Lipscomb called ‘this largely futile attempt’ - is our disinvestment in education,” the paper noted.  “Investment in education is about the future, and it is about hope. Investment in prisons and especially in the death penalty is about a final reckoning, an admission of gross failure.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Oregon Chapter of Physicians for Social Responsibility expresses deep concern that Oregon law continues to include the death penalty as a possible consequence for certain criminal offences.

 

The Oregon Chapter of Physicians for Social Responsibility expresses deep concern that Oregon law continues to include the death penalty as a possible consequence for certain criminal offences.

 

Guided by the values and expertise of medicine and public health, Physicians for Social Responsibility works to protect human life from the gravest threats to health and survival.  PSR is the medical and public health voice working to prevent the use or spread of nuclear weapons and to slow, stop and reverse global warming and toxic degradation of the environment.  The death penalty is a direct threat to human life, and has consistently been shown to be ineffective and unjust.

 

As health care providers and other concerned citizens, we adhere to the philosophy of “heal and do no harm”.  Therefore, as an organization, we voice our opposition to the death penalty everywhere, and urge the citizens of Oregon to invalidate Oregon law permitting this penalty in our state at the earliest possible time. 

 

As Oregon PSR believes that the death penalty is cruel, inhuman and degrading, we oppose its use in all cases regardless of the manner in which the crime was committed, the characteristics of the offender, or the method used to kill the prisoner.  While Europe and Central Asia are now virtually death penalty free zones, China, Iran, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan and the United States carry out 93% of all executions worldwide.

 

In December of 2008, the United Nations General Assembly adopted by a large majority a second resolution calling for a moratorium with a view to abolishing the death penalty.  This resolution consolidates three decades of steady progress towards complete abolition of the death penalty.

 

Oregon PSR encourages our members and the community to obtain detailed information on the death penalty from the following national and international organizations:

 

Amnesty International

http://www.amnesty.org/en/death-penalty

item.title: Catholic Mobilizing Network to End the Use of the Death Penalty
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Catholic Mobilizing Network (CMN) proclaims the Church’s unconditional pro-life teaching and its application to capital punishment and restorative justice. CMN works in close collaboration with the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops to prepare Catholics for informed involvement in campaigns to repeal state death penalty laws and expand or inaugurate restorative justice programs.

Our Mission

Catholic Mobilizing Network (CMN) proclaims the Church’s unconditional pro-life teaching and its application to capital punishment and restorative justice. CMN works in close collaboration with the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops to prepare Catholics for informed involvement in campaigns to repeal state death penalty laws and expand or inaugurate restorative justice programs.

What We Do

  • Educate the lay community through our programs and materials on the Church’s teachings on the death penalty.
  • Facilitate respectful and informed discourse within the Catholic community and the community at large.
  • Encourage informed Catholic involvement in the public debate.

CMN History

The Catholic Mobilizing Network to End Use of the Death Penalty (CMN) in the United States endeavors to take up the challenge of the U.S. bishops’ “Campaign To End the Use of the Death Penalty” (A Culture of Life and the Penalty of Death, 2005).

Late in the summer of 2008, veteran proponents of ending the death penalty gathered in Washington, D.C. to consider how best to engage lay American Catholics in the bishops’ campaign. Among them were Sister Helen Prejean, author of Dead Man Walking, and leadership from the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops, Catholic Charities USA, the Franciscan Action Network, the Maryland Catholic Conference, Catholics Against Capital Punishment, Murder Victims’ Families for Human Rights, the National Coalition To Abolish the Death Penalty, Equal Justice USA, and New Jerseyans for Alternatives to the Death Penalty.

The group determined that a national Catholic networking organization should be created to inform and facilitate the death penalty-related work of state Catholic conferences, diocesan offices, and other Catholic organizations and institutions. Among other services, the new organization would provide resource materials and education programs (in English and Spanish), workshops, speakers for conferences and special events, and a website with downloadable media.

Thanks to the involvement of Vicki Schieber, a nationally recognized spokesperson for Murder Victims’ Families for Human Rights, it was also determined that restorative justice, which seeks to repair the hurt caused by the violent taking of human life, should be integral to CMN’s work.

CMN was formally launched on January 25, 2009.

Numbering more than 67 million, Catholics comprise about 22 percent of our nation’s 309 million citizens. In states where repeal efforts have succeeded, or have made greatest headway, Catholics have been in the advocacy vanguards. Firm in the conviction that Catholics can make the difference, CMN seeks significantly to increase the number of American Catholics who embrace the Church’s death-penalty teaching and, with that teaching as their basis, work for the end of all state capital punishment laws.

Karen Clifton, Catholic Mobilizing Network to End the Use of the Death Penalty, August, 2009

http://catholicsmobilizing.org/

item.title: April, 2011 Update Newsletter
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
News from the Capitol

 

News from the Capitol

The 2011 Oregon Legislature convened in February with several bills related to the death penalty pre-filed in both houses.  HB 3211, the only expansion bill, would add murder of a reserve police officer as an aggravating factor triggering a possible death sentence.  The bill had a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee on March 17 and is still pending in committee.

Six other bills, SB 365 to 370, would have the effect of reducing the number of capital prosecutions and death sentences in Oregon.   They deal generally with the following elements:  (a) Guiding the discretion of district attorneys to seek the death penalty;  (b) Shifting some or all of the cost of capital prosecutions from the state to the county under certain circumstances; (c) Expanding the scope and nature of the Supreme Court’s mandatory review of all death sentences to include proportionality review and mental retardation, among other things; and (d) Creating a settlement mechanism during the appeals process.  Jeff Ellis and Tom O'Connor of the OADP Board and Pat Ehlers of our Advisory Council testified in favor of the bills at a hearing April 4 before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Click here to read summaries of the bills.


Know Your Legislators!

Although OADP supports the Senate bills described above to reduce the number of capital prosecutions and death sentences in Oregon, our primary purpose remains the repeal of capital  punishment.  In an article at this link, OADP Chair Ron Steiner discusses our repeal strategy and the important role our supporters around the state can play in helping us get a referral bill passed in the Legislature.  Please click the link to learn where we're headed and how you can help.

OADP 2011 Annual Meeting .... A NEW DAY!

The regular Annual Meeting of OADP will become a major event for 2011. Mark your calendars for 7:00 p.m. on JUNE 8 ... "A NEW DAY" for our movement. The largest celebration ever for our organization will be held at St. Mary’s Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, 1716 NW Davis St. in Portland.

We have been fortunate to schedule a main speaker who has recently achieved national prominence for her efforts as the sponsor of the Illinois legislation to repeal that state’s death penalty. Representative Karen Yarbrough has agreed to be our featured speaker on a program that will be expansive, informative, entertaining and designed to stimulate even more energy behind the efforts to repeal the Oregon death penalty.

Rep. Yarbrough has been in the Illinois General Assembly since 2001. Her leadership in getting SB3539 passed was praised and honored throughout the state of Illinois and the nation. A third generation entrepreneur in the real estate and insurance business, Rep. Yarbrough has a BA in Business Management from Chicago State University and an MA in Inner City Studies from Northeastern Illinois University. She represents the 7th District, which includes the North and downtown areas of Chicago. Representative Yarbrough has been a champion of progressive causes and has a long list of achievements in support of disenfranchised communities. She is presently the Assistant Majority Leader of the House.

Rep. Yarbrough’s legislative themes have been public health and public safety. She has been a stalwart fighter to help those incarcerated resume responsible citizenship and to fund programs that provide a "second chance."

The progressive tone of the NEW DAY program will be heralded by the popular and entertaining Portland area group, THE AURORA CHORUS. Since 1992, Aurora Chorus has honored the strength and beauty of women’s lives through the fine art of choral singing. The Aurora Chorus was founded on the belief that music can be a powerful instrument of peace, locally, globally, and in the hearts of all who listen and all who sing. The singing of the Aurora Chorus will inspire and reflect the universal yearning for peace, which is an underlying aspect of our work toward repeal.  For a preview, visit their website.

Please plan to join us for an inspiring and energizing evening!

Up-Coming Events

  • April 10, 10:00 a.m.:    Naseem Rakha, Advisory Council member and author of The Crying Tree, will speak to the Mid-Columbia Unitarian Universalist Fellowship, at The Rockford Grange, 4262 Barrett Drive, Hood River.
  • April 16, 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. at First United Methodist Church, 680 NW Bond, in Bend:  Free public seminar, discussion and dialogue:  the death penalty from multiple viewpoints.  Led by Rev. Thomas Larson of FUMC, and OADP Board and Advisory Council members.  Lunch included. Sure to be a deep, thought-provoking conversation.  Pre-registration appreciated by April 13 at (541) 382-1672.
  • April 22, 3:00 p.m. at Lincoln City First Congregational Church of Christ.  Ecumenical dialogue meeting. Please encourage any friends, associates and relatives who live on the Coast between Newport and Pacific City to attend.  Another thought-provoking conversation.
  • June 8, 7:00 p.m.:  Annual Meeting at St Mary’s Cathedral, 1716 NW Davis, Portland. Featured speaker is Rep. Karen Yarbrough, of Illinois, the sponsor of Senate Bill # 3539 to repeal the Illinois death penalty. Plus other local speakers and the Aurora Chorus.
  • August 14, 10:00-11:30 a.m.:  OADP Chair Ron Steiner will speak to Humanists of Greater Portland  at the Friendly House Community Center, main entrance on the SW corner of NW 26th and Thurman.
  • Week of Oct. 17: Sister Helen Prejean will return to Oregon. She will appear at multiple events that week in Eugene, Salem and Portland. Details are being worked out presently. More information to come.

OADP is pleased to participate in other public events of all sorts, including meetings, Sunday school sessions, school classes, book clubs, or any occasion where people gather to discuss issues that deal with social justice. Please help us schedule such events where you may have connections.

Legal Professionals for Replacement of Oregon’s Death Penalty

     We support replacing Oregon’s death penalty with a sentence of life in prison with no chance of parole as the maximum punishment for aggravated murder.  This means convicted killers will remain behind bars forever  –  with no risk of executing an innocent person.

item.title: Oregon Center for Christian Voices Proclamation Against Capital Punishment
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Oregon Center for Christian Voices believes that capital punishment is unjust and immoral.  Jesus embodied an ethics of love and forgiveness, and taught that all humans, whatever their faults and crimes, are capable of redemption.


Who are we to deny another person the opportunity to confess their sins and seek forgiveness?

State sponsored killings are barbaric and have no place in a civilized society.  How can we condemn gang member shootings if the state itself sanctions killing?  The state is responsible for justice, not vengeance. Those who are found guilty should be punished, but not by adding to the violence that already permeates our society and our world.
OCCV is concerned that innocent men and women have been condemned to death for crimes they did not commit.

According to Death Penalty Information Center, since 1973 over 130 people have been released from death row due to new evidence of their innocence.  DNA has helped to quicken the pace of these exonerations in recent years, but the #1 cause of mistakes has been prosecutorial misconduct.  The reality is that our judicial system is imperfect and flawed and may result in the ultimate injustice – taking the life of an innocent person.

                                                                     To the crowd around the woman caught in adultery Jesus said,
                                                                      “He who is without sin, let him throw the first stone.” (John 8:7)

Given our own sinful nature, harsh judgment against others for their sin with a sentence of capital punishment cannot be sanctioned.

The death penalty is unjust, since it is applied unequally to those without the means for adequate defense.  On moral, religious and humanitarian
grounds, OCCV urges Oregonians to repeal the death penalty.

item.content:encoded:
Declaration and Affirmation of Position on the Death Penalty from Oregon’s Unitarian Universalist Association Ministers.

 

Declaration and Affirmation of Position on the Death Penalty from Oregon’s Unitarian Universalist Association Ministers.

 

Beginning in 1961, delegates from the member congregations of Unitarian Universalist Association have voted in favor of abolishing the death penalty no less than six times. Likewise,

 

we, the undersigned, Unitarian Universalist ministers in the state of Oregon, again call for an end to capital punishment in our State.

 

We oppose the death penalty because:

 

our Unitarian Universalist Principles and Purposes call for us to acknowledge the “inherent worth and dignity of every person:”

 

the death penalty fails to act as a deterrent;

 

with the imperfect legal justice systems that we have, the death penalty puts innocent people are at risk of being executed;

 

it is racially and socio-economically discriminatory in its application disproportionately affecting racial and

ethnic minorities and the poor, who cannot afford adequate legal counsel;

 

it is costlier than alternatives, such as life imprisonment without parole, and drains scarce resources away from badly needed human services;

 

it is spiritually and psychologically harmful to those who are commissioned by the state to execute others;

 

it engenders a mindset of violence and retribution in society at large, exacerbating, rather than alleviating the problem it purports to solve.

 

Therefore we urge the citizens of Oregon to abolish the death penalty.

 

We also urge our elected State officials to do everything in their power to pass legislation leading to the abolition of this cruel and barbaric practice.

 

Signed: The Reverend Richard R. Davis, Unitarian Universalist Congregation of Salem, Oregon

 

(followed by all the other signatures of UU ministers) --

 

 

The Reverend Richard R. Davis

Unitarian Universalist Congregation of Salem

5090 Center St., N.E. Salem, Oregon 97317

item.title: United Church of Christ
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Resolution Supporting Abolition of the Death Penalty

 

Resolution Supporting Abolition of the Death Penalty

 

WHERE AS, fifteen states to date have abolished the death penalty, with active repeal efforts at work in other states. The death penalty has been abandoned in most countries of Western Europe and North and South America except the United States. The US stands with China, Iran and Iraq as one of the major users of the death penalty. However, there is a growing consensus that support for the death penalty is waning in the US.

 

WHEREAS, church organizations in Oregon are studying the abolition of the death penalty. They hope, through education of local churches and lobbying of the legislature, to persuade the 2011 Oregon legislature to adopt a public ballot measure for that purpose. Oregonians with Alternatives to the Death Penalty (OAPD) believes this will be possible if 2000 church members in Oregon join in this effort. The United Church of Christ was instrumental in starting the movement to abolish the death penalty in 1969 and has adopted resolutions for that purpose in subsequent general synods.

 

AND WHEREAS, it is time for the state of Oregon to abolish the death penalty, and it is time for churches and church members to assume leadership to see that this is accomplished. We as Christians are called to seek justice for the families and survivors of murder victims as well as for the condemned prisoners. Some families and survivors think executions will make them feel better but later find that they do not feel better. Prisoners on death row face a horrible fate, knowing the exact time and method of their impending deaths. Some of them are innocent and are there because of irregularities in the justice system, their race, or their poverty. Jesus calls us to reach out to these people.

 

This resolution has no budgetary implication.

 

THEREFORE, it is resolved by the Central Pacific Conference of the United Church of Christ that the death penalty should be abolished and that all local churches and affiliates of the UCC be urged to take the following actions:

              1. Preach and conduct educational programs to inform their congregations and other of the issues concerning the abolition of the death penalty, and

              2. Prepare to join in cooperation with the OADP or other groups to conduct a lobbying campaign to persuade the Oregon Legislature to adopt a   ballot measure to abolish the death penalty.

 

Adopted by the Assembly on day of May, 2009

 

Submitted with request that this resolution be considered.

 

Rev. James B Ruyle              Karen Kulm, Chair, Justice and               Rev. Jennifer Browwell

Member Hillsdale UCC           Witnesses Ministries Team                     Pastor Hillsdale UCC

Dear Members and Friends of the Oregon-Idaho Annual Conference,

 

June 2009

Dear Members and Friends of the Oregon-Idaho Annual Conference,

 

An opportunity to put our faith into practice calls us to a challenging journey of personal and social holiness as disciples of Jesus Christ. I invite you and your congregation to join me in an effort to abolish the death penalty in Oregon and Idaho. Your church can help in this effort in one of two ways: (1) you can sign up to participate in a “call to action” and join others in our region who are working to abolish the death penalty, or (2) your church can commit to study the issue of the death penalty in the coming year to determine how you might become involved in this issue.

 

My faith and personal convictions are foundational to my support of this effort. I find encouragement in words from Ezekiel 33:11: “Says to them, ‘As surely as I live, declares the Sovereign Lord, I take no pleasure in the death of the wicked, but rather that they turn from their ways and live.” Though faith in Jesus Christ we trust in the power of God to change the human spirit. The death penalty takes away human life and denies any possibility of that redeeming power of Christ to bring repentance and healing.

 

For many years, our Annual conference session has passed standing resolutions calling for all of us to work to end the death penalty in Oregon and Idaho. Now is the time for us to put our words into action. Both Idaho and Oregon continue to sentence people to die for heinous crimes. In Idaho, there are 10 persons currently on death row; and Oregon, there are 33(1). Since 1976, one person has been executed in Idaho and 2 in Oregon. While I do not condone criminal activity, I believe that there are other more effective means of bringing about justice than by the taking of a person’s life.

 

In Oregon, efforts are being mounted that hopefully will lead to the repeal of the death penalty in 2011.  Your voice is critical to encourage your state legislators to place an initiative before the people of Oregon. Once that is accomplished, your vote will demonstrate that faith in Jesus leads us into Christ-like action.

 

For the state of Idaho, efforts are being made to connect with our sisters and brothers in Christ in the Pacific Northwest Conference, which includes part of the state of Idaho as well as with legislators and organizations that are interested in joining in this effort.

 

The Social Principles of the United Methodist Church affirm: “We believe the death penalty denies the power of Christ to redeem, restore, and transform all human beings….We believe all human life is sacred and created by God and therefore, we must see all human life as significant and valuable.” (Social Principles, 164G)) These strong words remind us that God is the author of life and that all persons are beloved by God, even when we turn away from God. We place our trust in Christ’s ability to affect real change in the human heart and soul.  The existence of the death penalty negates these understandings of our faith. (2)

 

 

 

 

(1) Text says 35, but two people were taken off Oregon’s death row after printing of this document.

(2)  Final paragraph not included here….it included a re-statement of asking for participating for all members.

item.title: Press Release: More Mistakes Found In Death Row Convictions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Within the past two weeks two more men have left a death row prison, found innocent after serving years for crimes that did not commit. These two exonerations mark #134 and #135 since 1973, and five already in the first seven months of 2009. “The five exonerations this year demonstrate that innocent people still face a significant danger of execution in this country”, said Richard Dieter, Executive Director of the Death Penalty Information Center.
For Immediate Release July 29, 2009
More Mistakes Found In Death Row Convictions
Within the past two weeks two more men have left a death row prison, found innocent after serving years for crimes that did not commit. These two exonerations mark #134 and #135 since 1973, and five already in the first seven months of 2009.
“The five exonerations this year demonstrate that innocent people still face a significant danger of execution in this country”, said Richard Dieter, Executive Director of the Death Penalty Information Center. Dr. Bill Connor, retired physician and medical school instructor at OHSU and President of the Board of Directors for Oregonians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty (OADP) stated….”The mistakes that are made under our flawed death penalty system is amble evidence that it is time to repeal the death penalty in Oregon and other states”.
All charges were dismissed against Ronald Kitchen and he was released from prison in Illinois after spending almost 13 years on death row for murders prosecutors now concede cannot be proven. In the case of Mr. Kitchen, he had confessed to the crime after being subjected to interrogation by a police unit that used torturous tactics against the suspect.
In the second July exoneration, the Florida Supreme Court unanimously ordered that Herrman Lindsey be set free because there wasn’t enough evidence to convict him of murdering a Fort Lauderdale pawnshop worker. Lindsey’s exoneration was the 23rd in Florida since the reinstatement of the death penalty in 1976.
Oregon’s death row housed thirty three men at this time. Nationwide, there are over 3200 people on states’ and federal death row prisons. Since reinstatement of the death penalty in 1976 there have been 1,136 executions. Dr. Bill Long, former Willamette University Law School professor and author of a distinguished book on Oregon’s death penalty, says, “The number of mistakes and wrongful convictions are an abomination. Beyond that, we in Oregon should be looking at the tremendous cost of maintaining this fatally flawed system.. There have only been two executions in the past 30 years in the state, both men gave up their rights to appeal……yet we continue to spend millions of taxpayer dollars to have a death penalty …..its time for a change.”
For more information on the two recent exonerations, go to the web sites of the Miami Herald and the Chicago Tribune.
For more information on OADP, contact Ron Steiner, (503) 375-9218, rsteiner@swcp.com

item.title: Press Release: Oregon Peace Works Supports Abolition
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Oregon Peace Works Steps Up in Support of Abolition - Joining several secular and religious organizations, Oregon Peace Works has reaffirmed a position against Oregon’s death penalty.
For Immediate Release Aug. 7, 2009
Oregon Peace Works Steps Up in Support of Abolition
Joining several secular and religious organizations, Oregon Peace Works has reaffirmed a position against Oregon’s death penalty. Joining in support of Oregonians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty (OADP), Oregon Peace Works is an important member organization of a growing coalition supporting repeal in Oregon. With a mission “to educate and activate people to work for peace, justice and environmental sustainability”, Oregon Peace Works has a long and successful history of supporting progressive causes.
Regarding the death penalty, Executive Director Peter Bergel, says, “Almost all of us know in our hearts that killing others feels wrong. Moreover, it is ineffective as a deterrent and expensive as a punishment. That leaves only ‘getting even’ as a motivation and that’s not worth it.”
According to their vision, peace implies action on behalf of a broad range of concerns. Oregon Peace Works is affiliated with a long list of progressive organizations working in Oregon and around the world. As a supporter of OADP, they are joining with ACLU, Amnesty International, Physicians for Social Responsibility, Ecumenical Ministries of Oregon, Oregon Criminal Defense Lawyers Association, Murder Victims Families for Reconciliation, Murder Victims Families for Human Rights, Salem-Keizer Coalition for Equality, Oregon League of Women Voters, Equal Justice USA, Silverton People of Peace and a growing list of Oregon based organizations in an effort to repeal the ineffective, expensive and flawed death penalty system.
Oregon is one of 35 states that still have a death penalty. Recent repeals in New Jersey and New Mexico, along with legislative action working toward repeal in another dozen states, reflect a growing public sentiment against the death penalty.
For more information on Oregon Peace Works, contact Mr. Bergel at pbergel@igc.org or go to their web site at www.orgeonpeaceworks.org. For more information about joining with Oregonians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty, as an individual or an organization, go to www.oadp.org or contact Ron Steiner at (503) 375-9218.

item.title: Oregonian: Texas judge ended day as death row appeal waited
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
As lawyers frantically tried to file the last-minute appeal that could have halted the execution of a death row inmate, the Texas judge who oversaw the only court who could hear it was preparing to shut the doors for the day. "We close at 5," Judge Sharon Keller told a court staffer Sept. 25, 2007. The appeal was never heard, and four hours later, convicted killer Michael Wayne Richard was executed. Now it's Keller who will be before a judge, facing charges that could end her career in a special trial that begins Monday in San Antonio.
SAN ANTONIO – As lawyers frantically tried to file the last-minute appeal that could have halted the execution of a death row inmate, the Texas judge who oversaw the only court who could hear it was preparing to shut the doors for the day.
"We close at 5," Judge Sharon Keller told a court staffer Sept. 25, 2007.
The appeal was never heard, and four hours later, convicted killer Michael Wayne Richard was executed. Now it's Keller who will be before a judge, facing charges that could end her career in a special trial that begins Monday in San Antonio. Denying the rights of a condemned man is among five judicial misconduct charges that Keller, the presiding judge of the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals, is up against.
Nicknamed "Sharon Killer" among critics for a tough-on-crime reputation crafted over the years, Keller is the highest-ranking judge in Texas to be put on trial by the state Commission on Judicial Conduct. The judge overseeing the trial will submit a report to the commission, which could dismiss the charges, issue a censure or suggest Keller be removed from the bench.
Keller, a Republican who has served on the court since 1994, has not spoken publicly since being charged in February. Her attorney, Chip Babcock, said the widely repeated narrative of what happened the day Richard was executed isn't accurate.
"The truth is, the court was never closed to them," Babcock said. "They always had the ability to file."
There's a lot more to the story than late paperwork.
On the morning of Richard's execution, the U.S. Supreme Court agreed to review a Kentucky case over whether unconstitutional pain and suffering was caused by a three-drug combination used in executions — the same lethal cocktail used in Texas.
Richard's lawyers sprung to work. The high court's decision opened a new window for a reprieve, but Richard's lawyers say the good timing of the Supreme Court case gave way that afternoon to bad luck: computer problems. E-mail failures slowed down drafting an appeal, they said.
The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals, the state's court of last resort for death row inmates, closed at 5 p.m. Richard was represented by the Texas Defender Service, which called the court and asked for more time.
Keller, who had left the court earlier that afternoon to meet a repairman at home, got a phone call from the court around 4:45 p.m. to ask if the clerk's office could stay open late. She said no, and the appeal never made it to the court. Richard was executed at 8:23 p.m.
A week later, Keller told the Austin American-Statesman that she was never given a reason behind the question, so she simply said, "We close at 5." According to depositions in the case provided to The Associated Press, Keller said she never knew Richard's lawyers were having technical issues.
"If there had been some comment about computer problems, I would have started thinking in a different direction," Keller said in a June deposition.
Keller had no right to turn away the appeal even if there was an explanation, said Neal Manne, a lawyer who represents Texas Defender Service, a nonprofit group that represents mostly indigent defendants in capital murder cases.
"Who cares? To me, it doesn't matter if they had computer problems at all," Manne said. "If what Judge Keller did was misconduct, the nature or existence of this computer issue doesn't change that."
The case was widely publicized around the country, and fallout from the Richard case flooded the commission with complaints from lawyers. Newspaper editorials roundly rebuked Keller, and a state lawmaker tried impeaching her.
Keller, 56, is expected to testify during the trial. Her defense will include allegations that Richard's lawyers exaggerated computer problems, and that they should have known an appeal could be given to a judge even if the clerk's office is closed. A duty judge was at the court that night.
By PAUL J. WEBER, Associated Press Writer

item.title: Judges’ Dissents for Death Row Inmates Are Rising
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
By JOHN SCHWARTZ -- It took just 80 words for a federal appeals court to deny Kevin Cooper’s most recent plea to avoid execution. But attached to that order was a forceful 101-page dissent by a judge, all but pleading to spare Mr. Cooper’s life. “The State of California may be about to execute an innocent man,” it began. The judge who wrote the dissent, William A. Fletcher of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, argued that the police and prosecutors had withheld and tampered with evidence in the case for decades; Judge Fletcher even accused the district court of having sabotaged the case.
It took just 80 words for a federal appeals court to deny Kevin Cooper’s most recent plea to avoid execution. But attached to that order was a forceful 101-page dissent by a judge, all but pleading to spare Mr. Cooper’s life.
“The State of California may be about to execute an innocent man,” it began.
The judge who wrote the dissent, William A. Fletcher of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, argued that the police and prosecutors had withheld and tampered with evidence in the case for decades; Judge Fletcher even accused the district court of having sabotaged the case.
Compared with the dry, mannerly prose found in many opinions, Judge Fletcher’s passion in Cooper v. Brown is startling. But these kinds of fervent, lonely dissents, urging that a prisoner’s life be spared, have noticeably increased in the last decade, compared with previous years, according to a review of death penalty opinions by The New York Times, as confirmed by experts in the field.
In dozens of capital cases in recent years, appeals court judges, some of whom have ruled in favor of the death penalty many times, have complained that Congress and the Supreme Court have raised daunting barriers for death row prisoners to appeal their convictions, and in many cases the judges have taken on their colleagues.
“There is an increasing frustration among federal judges throughout the system,” said Eric M. Freedman, a critic of the death penalty who teaches on the subject at Hofstra Law School.
Mr. Freedman predicted that the level of dissatisfaction would increase. “Judges are likely to have less and less patience for being hogtied by legalistic mumbo-jumbo,” he said, “which prevents them from reaching fair results.”
The law that generates much of the judges’ ire is the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996. Since its passage, the act has been cited in a half-dozen to two dozen dissents a year, often in language forceful enough to rival Judge Fletcher’s. The law, championed by legislators who believed prisoners were abusing the federal appeals process, restricts federal court review of state court decisions in death penalty cases and puts strong limits on the ability of condemned prisoners to file habeas corpus petitions to get their cases reconsidered.
In April, Judge Rosemary Barkett of the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, complained of the law’s “thicket of procedural brambles.” Dissenting from a decision by her colleagues, Judge Barkett noted that seven of the nine witnesses in the murder trial of Troy Davis, a death row inmate in Georgia, had recanted their testimony. To execute Mr. Davis without fully considering that evidence would be “unconscionable and unconstitutional,” wrote Judge Barkett, who has voted in more than 200 other cases to uphold the death penalty.
Judge Stephen Reinhardt of the Ninth Circuit, a critic of capital punishment, took on the constitutionality of the 1996 death penalty act itself in a dissent in the case of Andrew C. Crater, who had been convicted of taking part in a robbery and shooting spree that killed a Sacramento musician, James Pantages. Judge Reinhardt, appointed by President Jimmy Carter, wrote in 2007 that the act made “a mockery of the careful boundaries between Congress and the courts that our Constitution’s framers believed so essential to the prevention of tyranny.”
The dissents rarely have any practical effect in changing the outcome of the cases they address. But Howard J. Bashman, an appellate lawyer in Philadelphia, said such dissents were often directed toward audiences to come: the next appeals court, lawmakers and academics.
“You have to think that these judges do have some valid reason for putting all this effort into the exercise than just feeling better about it after they’re done,” Mr. Bashman said.
Judge Barkett, whom President Bill Clinton appointed, declined to discuss individual cases but agreed that a dissent tried to persuade many audiences — the first, in her case, being the other judges of her court, who circulate dissents among themselves as they are coming to a decision.
Judge Barkett said she did not see her opinions as “emotive,” adding that dissents were about policy, not feelings. But the feeling that motivates her to write them, she said, is “mostly frustration that I cannot make people see what I see.”
Judge Fletcher’s frustration was on display in the case of Mr. Cooper, who he concluded was “probably innocent” of the 1983 murders of Douglas and Peggy Ryen, their 10-year-old daughter Jessica and an 11-year-old houseguest, Christopher Hughes, who were hacked to death in the Ryens’ home.
Judge Fletcher argued that the evidence had been tainted by bumbling and misconduct and suggested that blood linking Mr. Cooper to the crime had been planted by overzealous investigators. And while the Ninth Circuit in 2004 ordered new DNA tests, Judge Fletcher wrote that the lower court had set conditions rendering the results useless. “There is no way to say this politely,” he wrote. “The district court failed to provide Cooper a fair hearing and flouted our direction to perform the two tests.”
Judge Fletcher, who declined to be interviewed, was appointed by Mr. Clinton.
Jesse H. Choper, a law professor at the University of California, Berkeley, said the judge was hardly a fierce opponent of capital punishment. “I don’t see him as someone who is unexceptionally opposed,” Mr. Choper said.
In the Cooper case, Chief Judge Alex Kozinski, appointed by President Ronald Reagan, was among 11 of the circuit’s 27 judges who joined dissents.
Elisabeth A. Semel, director of the Death Penalty Clinic at Berkeley, which trains lawyers to defend people facing the death penalty, said many jurists had been shaken by the rise of exonerations due to DNA evidence. “I think it’s been shattering to judges who had a fair amount of confidence in the system,” she said.
The next step in the Cooper case is a long-shot appeal to the Supreme Court, which Mr. Cooper’s lead lawyer, Norman C. Hile, said was likely to be filed this year.
Kent Scheidegger, the legal director of the Criminal Justice Legal Foundation, a group in Sacramento that favors the death penalty, said substantial claims of innocence in such appeals remained rare.
In Mr. Cooper’s case, Mr. Scheidegger said, the defendant has been given ample opportunity to exonerate himself. “It is high time to bring this case to a close,” Mr. Scheidegger said.
Judge Fletcher argued otherwise. “If he is innocent, the real killers have escaped,” he wrote. “They may kill again. They may already have done so.
“We owe it to the victims of this horrible crime, to Kevin Cooper, and to ourselves, to get this one right.”
SOURCE: The New York Times By JOHN SCHWARTZ Published: August 13, 2009 Kitty Bennett contributed research. Original Article can be found at http://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/14/us/14dissent.html

item.title: Pax Christ Statement of Support
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
STATEMENT BY PAX CHRISTI USA REGARDING THE DEATH PENALTY

 


STATEMENT BY PAX CHRISTI USA REGARDING THE DEATH PENALTY

 

Pax Christi USA (PCUSA) opposes the death penalty in all cases and without reservation.  We base our unconditional opposition to the death penalty on the Gospel of Jesus Christ and in the consistent ethic of life which teaches that all life is sacred from the moment it begins until its natural death. In the Gospels we see a nonviolent Jesus who taught and exemplified forgiveness, mercy, compassion and justice that was restorative and healing, always seeking to convert and correct rather than to condemn.  We believe that those who are guilty, even of the most heinous crimes, are still sacred in the eyes of our loving God who embraces all sinners as sons and daughters.

 

Our opposition to the death penalty must not be perceived as disregard for the victims of violent crimes and their families.  Healing of their pain must be fostered through special love and compassion; it cannot come about by further suffering and death.  We call on communities of faith to accompany them in their grief and pain and to extend to them the healing, restorative presence of the risen Christ.

 

We are convinced that the taking of human life by the state in response to violent crime neither heals individuals nor restores society. Rather, it promotes a harmful attitude of revenge.  Society can be protected from violent or serious crimes by the long-term incarceration of perpetrators.  We urge federal and state governments to seek alternatives to the death penalty that reflect intelligence, civility, compassion and justice. Restoration of society and healing of the victims, as well as reform and rehabilitation of the offenders, must be the goals of the criminal justice system.

 

Pax Christi USA acknowledges that the increasingly lethal violence in the U.S. has complex social causes and effects which do not render easy solutions.  PCUSA encourages governments at all levels to examine more closely the "root causes" of violence and crime in our society and to address them in order to reduce crime, increase safety and promote a healthy society. Such root causes include a pervasive disregard for human life at all levels of our society; growing child abuse and neglect; breakdown of stable families and communities; growing gaps in income and quality of life; racism and hatred directed at minority populations; and a lack of quality education, work opportunities and social services for millions of citizens.

 

Currently, over 3500 people are on death row. Over 600 people have been executed since 1977. Capital punishment in the U.S., as evidence shows, is often administered in a manner which targets minorities and allows innocent people to be executed.  Crime rates in different countries and states suggest that the threat of execution has no effect on capital crimes.

 

Although the U.S. was a key author of the United Nations Charter and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, our nation resists the 1998 U.N. Human Rights Commission resolution that calls for a moratorium on executions leading to total abolition.  The right to life, specifically, is a minimum and basic provision upheld repeatedly in international human rights documents.  Legalized execution in the United States undermines these international standards and teaches that violence is an acceptable way of dealing with violence.

 

As we begin the new millennium, and in the spirit of Jubilee Justice, PCUSA calls on the U.S. government and all state governments that retain the death penalty to suspend all executions and completely abolish the death penalty. We reiterate the words of Pope John Paul II on his historic 1999 trip to St. Louis, "I renew the appeal... for a consensus to end the death penalty, which is both cruel and unnecessary."  We call all Catholics and all who believe in the sanctity of life to raise their voices against the practice of legalized execution.

 

Approved by the National Council of Pax Christi USA on April 1, 2000

 

 

Pax Christi USA, 532 West 8th Street, Erie, PA 16502   Phone 814-453-4955, Fax 814-452-4784

info@paxchristiusa.org      www.paxchristiusa.org
